item.title: @KordingLab @ISDedal @OpenAI Why do you have more power in changing a company if you buy their stuff? Even if that were definitely true, you still draw a line somewhere: you wouldn't buy from a company that did sufficiently bad things, even if you thought you could change it more by buying their stuff.
item.description: @KordingLab @ISDedal @OpenAI Why do you have more power in changing a company if you buy their stuff? item.content:encoded: @KordingLab @ISDedal @OpenAI Why do you have more power in changing a company if you buy their stuff? Even if that were definitely true, you still draw a line somewhere: you wouldn't buy from a company that did sufficiently bad things, even if you thought you could change it more by buying their stuff.

item.title:
You deduct 50-100% of our pay, and people like me (and there are lot of us) start saying No.
Because none of that stuff is in our "workload models". We'll focus on the work that is in our own interests or the interests of our immediate students/department.

item.title: @KordingLab @JCashaback @PsychScientists @hariteja11 Yes, for sure. They have cleaved themselves from the motor control community we know and now run a parallel program. I'm not judging that per se and some cool stuff there but it's notable that feedback control itself is so fundamental for us and they are minimally represented.
